pageMeta.title: Environment at a Glance TEST
pageMeta.description: Emissions of greenhouse gases (GHGs) from human activities disturb the radiative energy balance of the earth-atmosphere system. They exacerbate the natural greenhouse effect, leading to temperature changes and other disruption of the earth's climate. Land use changes and forestry also play a role by altering the amount of greenhouse gases captured or released by carbon sinks

book.description: Emissions of greenhouse gases (GHGs) from human activities disturb the radiative energy balance of the earth-atmosphere system. They exacerbate the natural greenhouse effect, leading to temperature changes and other disruption of the earth's climate. Land use changes and forestry also play a role by altering the amount of greenhouse gases captured or released by carbon sinks

content.value: Total GHG emissions with respect to the world
GHG emission intensity GDP and per capita
Number of countries presenting NDC targets
Number of countries presenting carbon neutrality

Climate change is of global concern due to the environmental impacts and its consequences on social and economic systems. It threatens ecosystems and biodiversity, affects water resources, human settlements and the frequency and scale of extreme weather events, with significant impacts on food security, human well-being, socio-economic activities, and economic output.

Greenhouse gas (GHGs) emissions from human activities disturb the radiative energy balance of the earth’s atmosphere leading to temperature changes and other disruptions of the earth's climate. Mitigation is a human intervention to reduce the sources or enhance the sinks of greenhouse gases (IPCC, 2021).

Given the role of carbon in the environment, there are essentially two types of policy approaches to mitigate climate change. The first is to reduce, abate, or limit GHG emissions in economic processes by changing productive processes, energy sources or reducing material-use. The second is to strengthen the capacity of the environment to store carbon by protecting carbon intensive ecosystems or increasing their capacity to capture carbon emissions. Moreover, since GHG emissions have a global impact, reducing emissions anywhere in the world will have the same effect, giving rise to the need for a global policy approach to climate mitigation.

GHG emissions data for the LAC region is limited, with no comprehensive up to date official data and considerable gaps for most countries. Estimates suggest total gross emissions (excluding land use, land use change and forestry [LUCF]) amount to about 3.2 Gt of CO

e in 2019, representing approximately 6.7% of global GHG emissions (Figure 3). Despite not being a major contributor to climate change, emissions in LAC rose by 61% between 1990 and 2019 and the region has a significant potential for natural carbon capture, particularly around the amazon river basin. The region can therefore play a crucial role in future global mitigation efforts.
Note: Total emissions exclude land use, land use change and forestry (LULUCF).
Source: OECD et al. (2022), Latin American Economic Outlook 2022: Towards a Green and Just Transition, OECD Publishing, Paris,

content.value: Source: Climate Watch. 2022. Washington, DC: World Resources Institute. Available online at:

The centrepiece of the international climate governance regime is the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) negotiated at the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development (UNCED) in Rio de Janeiro in 1992. The Convention established a broad set of substantive principles, including the “common but differentiated responsibilities”, but does not contain binding commitments to reduce GHG emissions.

session of the Conference of Parties (COP) in Paris, on 12 December 2015, Parties to the UNFCCC reached a landmark agreement to combat climate change and to accelerate and intensify the actions and investments needed for a sustainable low-carbon future. The Paris Agreement (PA) sets out the goal of limiting average global warming to 2ºC above pre-industrial levels and identifies a further need for efforts to confine the increase to 1.5ºC.

The basis of the PA is a non-binding “bottom-up” approach. Countries submit contributions reflecting their highest possible ambition; these are referred to as “nationally determined contributions” (NDCs). NDCs present targets to progressively mitigate GHG emissions and enhance their adaptive capacity to climate change, together with information necessary for clarity, transparency and understanding.

LAC countries, through their NDCs, have established GHG emission targets for 2030. Twenty countries have also committed to carbon neutrality by 2050. Countries have set out a range of possible policy approaches to comply with their commitments. These vary from direct regulations, carbon pricing, reducing deforestation, among other approaches and efforts.

Environmental performance can be assessed by comparing GHG emissions against domestic objectives and international goals and commitments. This is also often referred to as “distance-to-target”. Through the Paris Agreement process, 33 LAC countries have submitted commitments to the UNFCCC, with the exception of Puerto Rico. However, there are differences across the countries’ NDCs in terms of clarity, information details, and gas and sectoral coverage. Only 20 countries presented NDCs that are clear enough to infer 2030 and beyond targets.
By 2022, 26 Latin American countries had updated their NDC targets, since their first submission

Uruguay, Mexico, Bahamas, Dominica, Haiti, Guatemala, Brazil, El Salvador, Argentina, Antigua and Barbuda, Belize, Barbados, Paraguay, Honduras, Saint Lucia, Colombia, Costa Rica, Dominican Republic, Panama, Nicaragua, Peru, Grenada, Cuba, Jamaica, Chile, and Suriname
, many of which presented an increase in ambition. Moreover, 23 have committed net zero targets by 2050 (Net Zero Tracker, 2023).

Antigua and Barbuda, Argentina, Bahamas, Barbados, Belize, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Grenada, Guyana, Jamaica, Mexico, Nicaragua, Panama, Peru, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Suriname, and Trinidad and Tobago have

However, countries have made commitments with different legal status, for example, Chile’s targets are enshrined in a climate law, those in Bolivia, Colombia, Costa Rica Mexico and Peru do not have legal status. Chile, Colombia and Costa Rica detail separate reduction and removal targets in their commitments.
Nationally Determined Contributions in Latin America and the Caribbean

Total emissions excluding LULUCF in MTCO2e
Emissions as scope defined in NDC 2030 target in MTCO2e

Note: a negative distance to target shows the percentage a country needs to reduce to reach the target. A positive distance to target shows that a country aims to increase emissions. The column “Emissions as scope defined in NDC 2030 target in MTCO2e” shows total emissions covering sectors and gases that are specified in the NDC 2030 target. When detailed sectoral and gas level data is not available, the closest disaggregated official data available is taken to calculate “Emissions as scope defined in NDC 2030 target in MTCO2e”, for instance for Dominica, Dominican Republic, and Saint Lucia. Empty cells indicate whether data is not available or sufficient information is not available to estimate the country’s 2030 target.

Source: OECD (2023), "Air and climate: Greenhouse gas emissions by source", OECD Environment Statistics (database), https://doi.org/10.1787/data-00594-en (accessed on 10 February 2023); UNFCCC. 2022. Greenhouse Gas Inventory Data.
The indicators presented here show the sources and principal drivers of GHG emissions in LAC countries. They are complemented with intensities of carbon dioxide (CO
) emission from fuel combustion and information on the energy supply mix.

In line with GDP growth, the LAC region has experienced a steady increase in GHG emissions until 2014. Emissions stabilised and even decreased afterwards despite a rebound in economic activity, suggesting a relative decoupling. However, there are large differences across sub-regions. Between1990 and 2019, total gross emissions in the Caribbean increased by 26%, they increased by 68% in Central America and by 61% in South America (Figure 5).

The level of GHG emissions vary considerably across countries in the region. Brazil contributed about 32% of LAC’s gross total GHG emissions in 2019 while the top five emitters (Brazil, Mexico, Argentina, Venezuela, and Colombia) contributed about 78% and the top ten emitters contributed 90%.
Brazil, Mexico, Argentina, Venezuela, Colombia, Chile, Peru, Ecuador, Bolivia, Paraguay
The remaining 23 LAC countries generated 10% of the regions gross total GHG emissions.

The structure of emissions in LAC differs from that of the EU and OECD countries. While generation of electricity and heat is the first source of GHG emissions in OECD countries (accounting for about a third of net GHG emissions), followed by transport (representing about 25.5%), in LAC, agriculture is the most emitting sector (25.3% of the region’s net emissions). Land use, land us change and forestry (LULUCF) which act as a net sink in the OECD, is the second source of emissions representing about 19.5% of LAC net emissions.

These trends are driven by the structure of emissions in South America where agriculture and LULUCF account for respectively a third and a fourth of the sub-region’s net emissions. This in turn, reflects the significance of agriculture in the economy as well as the massive deforestation occurring in the region. Central America has a profile more similar to OECD countries with energy generation being the first source of emissions, followed by transport. In the Caribbean, energy generation is also the main source of GHGs but due to the relatively small size of Caribbean islands, transport is only the fourth source of emissions after agriculture and LULUCF (Figure 8) (Figure 9).

Since 1990, emissions from almost all sectors have grown continuously, in particular in the energy sector. This trend was driven by the growth of emissions from transport, followed by electricity and heat production. Emissions from agriculture increased by about 32% due to the rise in livestock breeding in South and Central America until 2010. While emissions from industrial processes and waste are lower, they have more than doubled since 1990 (OECD et al., 2022).

Forest loss is a major concern in the region, mainly driven by extensive conversion of land for agriculture, forestry, and, to a lesser extent, the expansion of urban areas. Deforestation in Brazil has accelerated since 2012 and although the areas involved are smaller, Nicaragua and Paraguay also have had high loss rates of forest in the last 20 years. On the other hand, Costa Rica and Chile managed to increase their forest cover through successful afforestation policies (OECD et al., 2022).

Transport is a major source of GHG emission, mainly due to the large size of many LAC countries and reliance of the sector to petroleum. In Latin American cities, private motorised transport is responsible for 75% of CO

pollutants. The Caribbean has one of the highest vehicle motorisation rates in the world, with 201 vehicles per 1 000 inhabitants. In LAC countries, the urban layout and the availability and quality of public transport favour automobile use and shape car-dependent and sprawled territories. The intensity of GHG emissions of the region’s transport sector (relative to GDP) are 2.2 times higher than in Europe and 1.3 times higher than Asia (OECD et al., 2022).

Source: OECD et al. (2022), Latin American Economic Outlook 2022: Towards a Green and Just Transition, OECD Publishing, Paris,
Source: Climate Watch. 2022. Washington, DC: World Resources Institute. Available online at:

In 2019, the per capita level of GHG emissions in LAC was similar to the global average but lower than the OECD one. However, there are significant differences across countries and sub regions. The Caribbean countries show high intensities due to emissions generated by non-residents (i.e. tourism), although Suriname, Chile, Argentina, Guyana and Venezuela also have high intensity levels (OECD et al., 2022). (Figure 8 and 9)
GDP per unit of energy-related CO
emissions, US dollars per kilogram, 2015 prices and PPPs, 2020 or latest
Source: OECD, "Green growth indicators", OECD Environment Statistics (database),
, based on OECD and IEA data.
Source: OECD, "Green growth indicators", OECD Environment Statistics (database),
, based on OECD and IEA data.

The region’s energy supply mix remains dominated by fossil fuels (66% in 2020), although renewables account for a much larger share (33%) than in OECD (12%) and the rest of the world (13%). The main sources of renewables in LAC are hydroelectric power, and biofuels such as firewood and bagasse (OECD et al., 2022). In some countries such as Brazil, Costa Rica, Haiti, Honduras, Nicaragua, Paraguay and Uruguay, the share of renewables in the energy mix is above 40% while it is less than 10% in Argentina, Guyana, Mexico and Trinidad and Tobago. There is almost no use of nuclear energy in the region. Although energy produced with coal has been decreasing across the region, many LAC countries remain highly dependent (e.g. Chile, Colombia, the Dominican Republic and Guatemala) (Figure 10 and 11).

In 2020, renewable energy accounted for 61% of regional electricity generation, broken down as 75% from hydroelectricity and 25% from solar, wind, biomass and geothermal. Central America has shown the greatest increases in renewables in the last two decades, from 65% to 77%. However, significant variations exist across the region. While Brazil generates 84% of its electric power from renewables, Jamaica relies on imported oil derivatives for 87% of its electricity generation (OECD et al., 2022).

Since renewable energy is focussed on hydroelectricity, representing X% of total energy supply, this also implies significant risks as changing rainfall patterns and increasing drought may affect the capacity of energy systems to respond. In Chile, extended drought already affected considerably hydroelectric generation capacity.
Renewables in LAC: The RELAC initiative

Renewables in Latin America and the Caribbean (RELAC) is a regional initiative created in 2019 within the framework of the United Nations Climate Action Summit. It has 15 member countries in the LAC region that have voluntarily agreed to promote renewables with: 1) a concrete goal; 2) a monitoring scheme; and 3) an operating structure designed to support countries in the process. The initiative’s general goals are to accelerate the carbon neutrality of electricity systems in LAC; improve the resilience, competitiveness and sustainability of the sector; and create green jobs, improving air quality and minimising harmful health effects for Latin Americans. To do this, RELAC aims to establish a climate action platform for LAC countries and international organisations to enable sharing sustainable solutions.

The RELAC initiative aims to reach at least 70% of renewable energy participation in the region’s electricity matrix by 2030. Two conditions are needed to achieve these targets. The first is to invest 1.3% of regional GDP for ten years, equivalent to USD 114 per capita (i.e. USD 80 billion in constant 2010 prices), with some countries needing a greater or lesser proportion of GDP depending on local circumstances. The second is to increase renewables technologies (mostly solar and wind) in line with the targets of Sustainable Development Goal 7 (SDG 7) on access to affordable and clean energy. These actions could create 7 million green jobs and reduce GHG emissions by 30% by 2030.
Source: OECD calculations based on IEA, "World energy statistics", IEA World Energy Statistics and Balances (database),

content.value: Total energy supply includes electricity trade. Renewables include hydro, geothermal, solar (thermal and PV), wind and tide/wave/ocean energy, as well as combustible renewables (solid biomass, liquid biomass, biogas) and waste (renewable municipal waste).
Source: OECD calculations based on IEA, "World energy statistics", IEA World Energy Statistics and Balances (database),

Official GHG emissions data made available through UNFCCC inventories and OECD questionnaire are incomplete. For instance, between 1990 and 2017, official emissions data is missing for at least seven LAC countries. Estimated values from Climate Watch Historical GHG Emissions data provided by the World Resource Institute (WRI) have been used to complement missing information (Climate Watch, 2022).

The Climate Watch dataset covers all parties to the UNFCCC, all gasses and main IPCC sectors. The data, however, has limitations. It does not use countries’ official inventory data and comparability with official national data is limited. The Climate Watch data follows IPCC’s guidelines to compile the sectoral emissions drawing on sources that have been widely adopted including IEA’s GHG Emissions from Fossil Fuel Combustion, FAO’s agriculture and land use emissions data, US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)’s non-CO2 gases emissions data, and fossil related CO2 emissions from the Global Carbon Project.

emission intensity estimates are affected by the quality of the underlying energy data, but in general the comparability across countries is quite good. Carbon productivity indicators inform on the relative decoupling between economic activity and emissions. They provide insight into how much carbon productivity has improved. Reductions in national emissions can also be achieved by offshoring domestic production and, thus, the related emissions. Evidence of decoupling based on domestic emissions, therefore, may reveal only part of the story.
